comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+# Generated by Django 3.2.19 on 2023-10-19 23:46
+
+from django.db import migrations, models
+
+
+class Migration(migrations.Migration):
+    dependencies = [
+        ("emails", "0057_profile_sent_welcome_email"),
+    ]
+
+    operations = [
+        migrations.AddField(
+            model_name="profile",
+            name="onboarding_free_state",
+            field=models.PositiveIntegerField(default=0),
+        ),
+    ]
comment.body: It's a mix of updating the query from the command to apply the right default. I'll follow-up with documentations to do this on [MPP-3464](https://mozilla-hub.atlassian.net/browse/MPP-3464). I provided a [review](https://github.com/mozilla/fx-private-relay/pull/3961#pullrequestreview-1700549235) for the updated migration.

pull_request.title: MPP-3443 & MPP-3444 - Free user onboarding experience
pull_request.body:
<!-- The following is intended to be helpful to you. Feel free to remove anything that is not. -->

<!-- When fixing a bug: -->

This PR fixes MPP-3443 & MPP-3444
  
# New feature description

Figma: https://www.figma.com/file/VWDfo6NG52RbGmWGfuKX2F/Improved-Onboarding-for-Free-Relay-Users?type=design&node-id=725-1791&mode=design&t=4MiMImZYht3nGuQz-0 

- Has all three steps - welcome to relay, copy your mask to use it, use your masks everywhere.
- Second step (copy your mask to use it) has additional functionality to try out email forwarding, which triggers sending email.
- Third step checks if extension is installed.
- Congratulatory animation is triggered when user finishes onboarding.
- Onboarding state is updated for user so they don’t go through onboarding again. 

Implement the additional functionality needed for the second step of the free user onboarding, where a user can copy their mask and see additional information about their mask. This is broken into its own task as it doesn’t block the overall flow of onboarding. 

Majority of UI has been reused from existing screens. This will require a few new strings, but overall, it will require a bit of QA testing. 

# Screenshot (if applicable)

 https://vimeo.com/871702930/e8c8afdf67?share=copy

# How to test

- Make sure user profile you are using has onboarding state set to 0 - you can do this from the admin dashboard. 
- `free_user_onboarding` flag should be turned on as well. 

# Checklist (Definition of Done)
- [ ] Product Owner accepted the User Story (demo of functionality completed) or waived the privilege.
- [ ] All acceptance criteria are met.
- [ ] Jira ticket has been updated (if needed) to match changes made during the development process.
- [ ] I've added or updated relevant docs in the docs/ directory
- [ ] Jira ticket has been updated (if needed) with suggestions for QA when this PR is deployed to stage.
- [ ] All UI revisions follow the [coding standards](https://github.com/mozilla/fx-private-relay/blob/main/docs/coding-standards.md), and use Protocol tokens where applicable (see `/frontend/src/styles/tokens.scss`).
- [ ] Commits in this PR are minimal and [have descriptive commit messages](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/).
- [ ] l10n changes have been submitted to the l10n repository, if any.

repo.name: fx-private-relay
repo.description: Keep your email safe from hackers and trackers. Make an email alias with 1 click, and keep your address to yourself.

- Second step (copy your mask to use it) has additional functionality to try out email forwarding, which triggers sending email.
- Third step checks if extension is installed.
- Congratulatory animation is triggered when user finishes onboarding.
- Onboarding state is updated for user so they don’t go through onboarding again. 

Implement the additional functionality needed for the second step of the free user onboarding, where a user can copy their mask and see additional information about their mask. This is broken into its own task as it doesn’t block the overall flow of onboarding. 

Majority of UI has been reused from existing screens. This will require a few new strings, but overall, it will require a bit of QA testing.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,161 @@
+# Generated by Django 3.2.19 on 2023-10-19 23:46
+
+from django.db import migrations, models
+
+
+def add_db_default_forward_func(apps, schema_editor):
+    """
+    Add a database default of false for sent_welcome_email, for PostgreSQL and SQLite3
+    Note: set sent_welcome_email = true for existing users
+
+    Using `./manage.py sqlmigrate` for the SQL, and the technique from:
+    https://stackoverflow.com/a/45232678/10612
+    """
+    if schema_editor.connection.vendor.startswith("postgres"):
+        schema_editor.execute(
+            'ALTER TABLE "emails_profile"'
+            ' ALTER COLUMN "onboarding_free_state" SET DEFAULT 0;'
+        )
+        # Set all existing profiles to 0 so we don't send them another welcome email
comment.body:
```suggestion
        # Set all existing profiles to 0 so existing users also see the free onboarding
```
Seems like copy paste error. Not sure if this will end up being the case since Product and Design is reconsidering who should see the free onboarding but is nice to have context on previous decisions.

@@ -125,6 +125,7 @@ class Profile(models.Model):

+    ]
+
+    operations = [
+        migrations.AddField(
+            model_name="profile",
+            name="onboarding_free_state",
+            field=models.PositiveIntegerField(default=0),
+        ),
+    ]
comment.body: Right, you have to create it manually. I've done it a few times - it might be easier for me to jump in?

pull_request.title: MPP-3443 & MPP-3444 - Free user onboarding experience
pull_request.body:
<!-- The following is intended to be helpful to you. Feel free to remove anything that is not. -->

<!-- When fixing a bug: -->

This PR fixes MPP-3443 & MPP-3444
  
# New feature description

Figma: https://www.figma.com/file/VWDfo6NG52RbGmWGfuKX2F/Improved-Onboarding-for-Free-Relay-Users?type=design&node-id=725-1791&mode=design&t=4MiMImZYht3nGuQz-0 

- Has all three steps - welcome to relay, copy your mask to use it, use your masks everywhere.
- Second step (copy your mask to use it) has additional functionality to try out email forwarding, which triggers sending email.
- Third step checks if extension is installed.
- Congratulatory animation is triggered when user finishes onboarding.
- Onboarding state is updated for user so they don’t go through onboarding again. 

Implement the additional functionality needed for the second step of the free user onboarding, where a user can copy their mask and see additional information about their mask. This is broken into its own task as it doesn’t block the overall flow of onboarding. 

Majority of UI has been reused from existing screens. This will require a few new strings, but overall, it will require a bit of QA testing. 

# Screenshot (if applicable)

 https://vimeo.com/871702930/e8c8afdf67?share=copy

# How to test

- Make sure user profile you are using has onboarding state set to 0 - you can do this from the admin dashboard. 
- `free_user_onboarding` flag should be turned on as well. 

# Checklist (Definition of Done)
- [ ] Product Owner accepted the User Story (demo of functionality completed) or waived the privilege.
- [ ] All acceptance criteria are met.
- [ ] Jira ticket has been updated (if needed) to match changes made during the development process.
- [ ] I've added or updated relevant docs in the docs/ directory
- [ ] Jira ticket has been updated (if needed) with suggestions for QA when this PR is deployed to stage.
- [ ] All UI revisions follow the [coding standards](https://github.com/mozilla/fx-private-relay/blob/main/docs/coding-standards.md), and use Protocol tokens where applicable (see `/frontend/src/styles/tokens.scss`).
- [ ] Commits in this PR are minimal and [have descriptive commit messages](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/).
- [ ] l10n changes have been submitted to the l10n repository, if any.

# New feature description

Removed the trailing slash, I'm assuming some browsers were not parsing it correctly. Link sends me to the correct page now.

# Screenshot (if applicable)

pull_request.title: MPP-3477: Log header issues
pull_request.body:
This PR addresses:

* MPP-3477 - `ValueError: Header values may not contain linefeed or carriage return characters` - This exact traceback no longer occurs, but may have moved to a different issue.
* MPP-3503 - `IndexError: list index out of range` - should fix
* MPP-3540 - `IndexError: list index out of range` - should also fix

This PR extends Python's [email.policy.default](https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.policy.html) as `relay_policy` to change how emails headers are parsed.  The changes are:

* Each email header has a new attribute `.as_unstructured` which represents the header if parsed as an unstructured header, rather than as an email address, date, etc. This allows logging something like the original value when the header is not RFC compliant.
* The `Message-ID` header parser now catches `IndexError` and treats the header as an unstructured header.

This allows loading test emails with non-compliant headers, so they don't need to be stored as SNS JSON fixtures.

It also enables logging defect data for headers when forwarding an email, under warning message `"_handle_received: forwarding issues"`. The new code uses try / except blocks when reading and writing headers, and logs any exceptions. This will mean a few more emails are processed without killing the email task, but in other cases the error will be logged but the email will fail later in the process. The main benefit is to be able to see which headers are non-compliant and plan on how to handle them.

This PR also serializes the email before calling `ses_client.send_raw_email`, which will hopefully make serialization errors easier to distinguish from other SES client errors.

## How to test:

This code adds extra logging for emails with headers that are not RFC compliant. I have not found a way to create these emails for interactive testing, so you'll have to be content with code inspection and automated testing.

- [x] I've added a unit test to test for potential regressions of this bug.
- [x] Commits in this PR are minimal and [have descriptive commit messages](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/).

repo.name: fx-private-relay
repo.description: Keep your email safe from hackers and trackers. Make an email alias with 1 click, and keep your address to yourself.

repo.name: fx-private-relay
repo.description: Keep your email safe from hackers and trackers. Make an email alias with 1 click, and keep your address to yourself.

commits.message: Add test for email with invalid Message-ID

Add .as_unstructured to headers

Extend header creation to include an element .as_unstructured, which
parses the header as if it was an unstructured header. This allows
getting the original value, after removing some whitespace.

Make create_notification_from_email more flexible

Use the new .as_unstructured field to allow
create_notification_from_email to create SNS notifications from emails
with headers that are not compliant with RFCs.
Detect and log issues with headers
Serialize message to string outside of call

Remove emails/headderegistry.py

Combine the code with that in emails/policy.py

Merge pull request #4035 from mozilla/log_header_issues_mpp_3477

MPP-3477: Log header issues

payload.description: Keep your email safe from hackers and trackers. Make an email alias with 1 click, and keep your address to yourself.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -799,23 +808,24 @@ def _convert_to_forwarded_email(
     sample_trackers: bool,
     remove_level_one_trackers: bool,
     now: datetime | None = None,
-) -> tuple[EmailMessage, int, bool, bool]:
+) -> tuple[EmailMessage, EmailForwardingIssues, int, bool, bool]:
     """
     Convert an email (as bytes) to a forwarded email.
 
     Return is a tuple:
     - email - The forwarded email
+    - issues - Any detected issues in conversion
     - level_one_trackers_removed (int) - Number of trackers removed
     - has_html - True if the email has an HTML representation
     - has_text - True if the email has a plain text representation
     """
-    email = message_from_bytes(incoming_email_bytes, policy=policy.default)
+    email = message_from_bytes(incoming_email_bytes, policy=relay_policy)
     # python/typeshed issue 2418
     # The Python 3.2 default was Message, 3.6 uses policy.message_factory, and
     # policy.default.message_factory is EmailMessage
     assert isinstance(email, EmailMessage)
 
-    _replace_headers(email, headers)
+    header_issues = _replace_headers(email, headers)
comment.body:
I'm not going to do this at this time.

I'm concerned about the extra memory usage if we intend to copy an email to change the headers, then again to change the text, and a third time to change the HTML, and then throw away those copies at the end of this function. We handle emails up to 10 MB, and hope to expand to 30 MB in the future. I think this is a case where any code smell is justified by the size of the data structures involved.

Additionally, the problem this PR is trying to address is that AWS SES is receiving emails with headers that Python can't write, because in several cases it refuses to write a non-compliant header. Copying an email requires writing an email, so changing to a functional style would trigger the very errors we are trying to detect and avoid.

I'd support inlining `_replace_headers` here and doing away with the function call entirely, if the style is too objectionable as it is.

pull_request.title: MPP-3477: Log header issues
pull_request.body:
This PR addresses:

* MPP-3477 - `ValueError: Header values may not contain linefeed or carriage return characters` - This exact traceback no longer occurs, but may have moved to a different issue.
* MPP-3503 - `IndexError: list index out of range` - should fix
* MPP-3540 - `IndexError: list index out of range` - should also fix

This PR extends Python's [email.policy.default](https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.policy.html) as `relay_policy` to change how emails headers are parsed.  The changes are:

* Each email header has a new attribute `.as_unstructured` which represents the header if parsed as an unstructured header, rather than as an email address, date, etc. This allows logging something like the original value when the header is not RFC compliant.
* The `Message-ID` header parser now catches `IndexError` and treats the header as an unstructured header.

This allows loading test emails with non-compliant headers, so they don't need to be stored as SNS JSON fixtures.

It also enables logging defect data for headers when forwarding an email, under warning message `"_handle_received: forwarding issues"`. The new code uses try / except blocks when reading and writing headers, and logs any exceptions. This will mean a few more emails are processed without killing the email task, but in other cases the error will be logged but the email will fail later in the process. The main benefit is to be able to see which headers are non-compliant and plan on how to handle them.

This PR also serializes the email before calling `ses_client.send_raw_email`, which will hopefully make serialization errors easier to distinguish from other SES client errors.

## How to test:

This code adds extra logging for emails with headers that are not RFC compliant. I have not found a way to create these emails for interactive testing, so you'll have to be content with code inspection and automated testing.

- [x] I've added a unit test to test for potential regressions of this bug.
- [x] Commits in this PR are minimal and [have descriptive commit messages](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/).

repo.name: fx-private-relay
repo.description: Keep your email safe from hackers and trackers. Make an email alias with 1 click, and keep your address to yourself.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,87 @@
+"""
+Implement Python's email.policy.Policy for Relay
+
+The library provides email.policy.default, which parses and generates RFC-compliant
+email headers. However, Relay needs to be able to handle emails with non-compliant
+headers as well.
+
+The main change is to use a custom header_factory, which:
+
+* For each header, adds the UnstructuredHeader variant as .as_unstructured
+* Handles non-compliant Message-IDs generated by Microsoft alerts
+
+See:
+https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.headerregistry.html
+https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.policy.html
+https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/main/Lib/email/_policybase.py
+https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/main/Lib/email/headerregistry.py
+https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/main/Lib/email/policy.py
+"""
+
+from email._header_value_parser import get_unstructured, InvalidMessageID
+from email.headerregistry import (
+    MessageIDHeader as PythonMessageIDHeader,
+    HeaderRegistry as PythonHeaderRegistry,
+    UnstructuredHeader,
+)
+from email.policy import EmailPolicy
+
+from email import errors
+
+from typing import cast, TYPE_CHECKING
+
+if TYPE_CHECKING:
+    # _HeaderParser is a protocol from mypy's typeshed
+    # https://github.com/python/typeshed/blob/main/stdlib/email/headerregistry.pyi
+    from email.headerregistry import _HeaderParser
+
+
+class RelayMessageIDHeader(PythonMessageIDHeader):
+    """
+    Handle an IndexError raised by parsing an invalid Message-ID header.
+
+    This issue is tracked in
+    https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/105802
+
+    A fix is unmerged as of October 2023:
+    https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/108133
+    """
+
+    @classmethod
+    def parse(cls, value, kwds):
+        try:
+            parse_tree = cls.value_parser(value)
+        except IndexError:
+            token = get_unstructured(value)
+            message_id = InvalidMessageID(token)
+            message_id.defects.append(
+                errors.InvalidHeaderDefect(
+                    f"IndexError for invalid msg-id in '{value}'"
+                )
+            )
+            parse_tree = message_id
+        kwds["parse_tree"] = parse_tree
+        kwds["decoded"] = str(parse_tree)
+        kwds["defects"].extend(parse_tree.all_defects)
+
+
+class RelayHeaderRegistry(PythonHeaderRegistry):
+    """Extend the HeaderRegistry to store the unstructured header."""
+
+    def __call__(self, name, value):
+        """Add the unstructured header as .as_unstructured."""
+        header_instance = super().__call__(name, value)
+        as_unstructured_cls = type(
+            "_UnstructuredHeader", (UnstructuredHeader, self.base_class), {}
+        )
+        as_unstructured = as_unstructured_cls(name, value)
+        header_instance.as_unstructured = as_unstructured
+        return header_instance
+
+
+relay_header_factory = RelayHeaderRegistry()
+relay_header_factory.registry["message-id"] = cast(
+    type["_HeaderParser"], RelayMessageIDHeader
+)
comment.body:
Nope, not needed. The special header handlers are listed in the docs (and the code): 

https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.headerregistry.html#email.headerregistry.HeaderRegistry

`in-reply-to-` and `references` do not have special handlers, so they are already handled by the default `UnstructuredHeader`. Using `RelayMessageIDHeader` for these could cause more problems then it solves.

pull_request.title: MPP-3477: Log header issues
pull_request.body:
This PR addresses:

* MPP-3477 - `ValueError: Header values may not contain linefeed or carriage return characters` - This exact traceback no longer occurs, but may have moved to a different issue.
* MPP-3503 - `IndexError: list index out of range` - should fix
* MPP-3540 - `IndexError: list index out of range` - should also fix

This PR extends Python's [email.policy.default](https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.policy.html) as `relay_policy` to change how emails headers are parsed.  The changes are:

* Each email header has a new attribute `.as_unstructured` which represents the header if parsed as an unstructured header, rather than as an email address, date, etc. This allows logging something like the original value when the header is not RFC compliant.
* The `Message-ID` header parser now catches `IndexError` and treats the header as an unstructured header.

This allows loading test emails with non-compliant headers, so they don't need to be stored as SNS JSON fixtures.

It also enables logging defect data for headers when forwarding an email, under warning message `"_handle_received: forwarding issues"`. The new code uses try / except blocks when reading and writing headers, and logs any exceptions. This will mean a few more emails are processed without killing the email task, but in other cases the error will be logged but the email will fail later in the process. The main benefit is to be able to see which headers are non-compliant and plan on how to handle them.

This PR also serializes the email before calling `ses_client.send_raw_email`, which will hopefully make serialization errors easier to distinguish from other SES client errors.

## How to test:

This code adds extra logging for emails with headers that are not RFC compliant. I have not found a way to create these emails for interactive testing, so you'll have to be content with code inspection and automated testing.

- [x] I've added a unit test to test for potential regressions of this bug.
- [x] Commits in this PR are minimal and [have descriptive commit messages](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/).

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -152,23 +153,42 @@ def create_notification_from_email(email_text: str) -> AWS_SNSMessageJSON:
     The SNS notification will have the headers from the email and other mocked items.
     The email will be included in the notification body, not loaded from (mock) S3.
     """
-    email = message_from_string(email_text, policy=policy.default)
+    email = message_from_string(email_text, policy=relay_policy)
     topic_arn = "arn:aws:sns:us-east-1:168781634622:ses-inbound-grelay"
+    if email["Message-ID"]:
+        message_id = email["Message-ID"].as_unstructured
+    else:
+        message_id = None
comment.body:
Yes, all the other headers are processed with that line.

I think I should also log differences between AWS headers and these unstructured headers - there's so many opportunities to misunderstand how SES processes our emails. Next PR...
